document.docAuthor: Spinelli, Gustavo R., Marino, Pablo I. & Borkent, Art
document.masterDocTitle: A revision of Biting Midges of the Subgenera Forcipomyia (Metaforcipomyia) and F. (Saliohelea) from Costa Rica (Diptera: Ceratopogonidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A revision of Biting Midges of the Subgenera Forcipomyia (Metaforcipomyia) and F. (Saliohelea) from Costa Rica (Diptera: Ceratopogonidae)

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Forcipomyia ( Saliohelea ) leei
Wirth & Ratanaworabhan, 1978
: 498
(female, male, pupa; Colombia );
Borkent & Wirth, 1997
: 47
(in catalog of world species);
Borkent & Spinelli, 2000
: 22
(in catalog of New World species south of the USA );
Borkent & Spinelli, 2007
: 57
(in catalog of Neotropical species).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. Male: only species of Neotropical
Forcipomyia ( Saliohelea )
with the length of the parameres always shorter than the length of the aedeagus. Female: only species of Neotropical
Forcipomyia ( Saliohelea )
with palpal segment 3 with a shallow sensory pit.

FIGURES 120–128.
Forcipomyia
( Saliohelea )
leei
Wirth
& Ratanaworabhan
.
120–123, male, 124–128, female. 120—flagellomeres 10–13; 121, 126—wing; 122—genitalia (ventral view); 123—aedeagus; 124—flagellum; 125—palpus 127—genital sclerotization; 128 spermathecae.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Female. As for male, with following differences; antenna with flagellomeres 1–8 subspherical, slightly longer than broad; progressively longer, flagellomeres 9–13 slightly elongate, 9–12 progressively shorter with proportions as shown in
Fig. 124
, flagellomere 13 with apical nipple, slightly constricted basally; AR 0.77–0.92 ( 0.84 , n = 16 ); palpus (
Fig. 125
) pale brown; segment 3 slender, moderately elongate, swollen at midlength, with broad, shallow sensory pit opening on distal third; segments 4, 5 completely fused, as long as segment 3 or slightly shorter; PR 1.89–2.90 ( 2.37 , n = 16 ).

Distribution.
Forcipomyia leei
is distributed from the eastern U.S.A. to southern Brazil . In Costa Rica (
Fig. 146
) it is found from sea level to 3017 meters, although most records are from higher elevations. Clearly, it is a common species in Costa Rica . Specimens from one locality in northwestern Costa Rica , appearing on the coast, was taken from a mangrove swamp. Othewise, all other
F . leei
in Costa Rica are known from wet, humid habitats.

Taxonomic discussion. Males and females were collected at the same locality and date. This species is similar to
F . ( Saliohelea ) digita
. Characters to distinguish males and females of both species are in the discussion section of
F . digita
.

Wirth & Ratanaworabhan ( 1978 )
, in their original description, noted that flagellomere 9 (as “segment 11 ”) of the female is unusually long, but this condition is not reflected in the figure of the female that accompained the description. In the specimens studied here flagellomere 9 is subequal in length to flagellomere 10 and slightly longer than flagellomere 8 .

There is surprising variation in this species. Higher elevation specimens are darker, the length of the spermathecae also varies greatly, and male and female palpal segment 3 are elongate and with a small pit in a series of specimens, or very short and with a big pit in others. Variation is also particularly evident in pigmentation of the legs. Males legs are entirely dark brown (high elevation specimens), or dark brown with basal third of forefemur pale, or very light brown with mid- and hind femora with a poorly defined dark band on their apical half, or very light brown with just the hind femur with a poorly defined dark band on its apical half or entirely pale or very light brown. Females legs are very light brown with fore-, mid- and hind femora with a poorly defined dark band on their apical half or dark apical bands on just the mid- and hind femora or just on the hind femur, or entirely pale or very light brown.

This variation suggests the presence of more than one species but we were unsuccessful in finding any discrete differences. Further material and perhaps investigation of the immatures may help to better understand this variation.

The female thorax is dark brown, with the dorsal portion of the katepisternum dark and its ventral half pale. The ventral half of the anepimeron is also pale. This appears to be consistent with the description of
Wirth & Ratanaworabhan ( 1978 )
: “Thorax dark brown, pleuron paler”.

Type material.
Holotype female, Colombia , Río Raposo, Valle, VI/
VII- 1963
, V. H. Lee ( USNM ). Allotype male, same data as holotype except
VII- 1965
, at light.

Two paratypes from the type locality were examined during this study:
1 male
(
July 1965
) and
1 female
( June 15, 1964 ).
